did.head: Overview
did.unittitle: Arthur Garfield Kennedy papers
did.abstract: Personal and professional correspondence, notes, reviews, notebooks, bibliography of writings on the English language, and other papers. Material relates to specific works of Dr. Kennedy on English philology and current use of English, Stanford University during World War II, scholarly groups to which Kennedy belonged, Stanford groups, and official Stanford agencies. Correspondents include Hardin Craig,, Helge Kökeritz, Lucia B. Mirrieless, Clark S. Northrup, Louise Pound, John S. P. Tatlock and Philip Sheridan.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Ownership & Copyright
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94304-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/pubserv/permissions.html.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Arthur Garfield Kennedy Papers (SC0044). Department of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Sketch
bioghist.p: Professor of English Philology at Stanford (1914-1945; emeritus 1945-1954) and Chairman of the English Department (1941-1945).

Arthur Garfield Kennedy was born on June 29, 1880, in Weeping Water, Nebraska. He received his A.B. from Doane College in 1902, and his A.M. degree from the University of Nebraska in 1905. He taught high school English and German until 1912 at which time he came to Stanford where he received his Ph.D. in English Philology in 1914. He began his career of teaching at Stanford in 1914 as an instructor, and advanced steadily in the department to the rank of Professor of English Philology in 1929. From 1941 until his retirement in 1945 he was executive head of the department. He died on April 21, 1954.

The contents of this collection consists primarily of Dr. Kennedy's correspondence with academic colleagues, though some personal letters are included. Of special interest is his wartime correspondence with Philip Sheridan, one of his graduate students, which contains accounts of Stanford and the English department during the war years. Also included in the collection are materials dealing with Dr. Kennedy's various published works, copie sof his earliest publications on grammar, some grade books from his years as a teacher, and copies of A concise Bibliography for Students of English and Bibliography of Writings on the English Language.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Collection
scopecontent.p: Personal and professional correspondence, notes, reviews, notebooks, bibliography of writings on the English language, and other papers. Material relates to specific works of Dr. Kennedy on English philology and current use of English, Stanford University during World War II, scholarly groups to which Kennedy belonged, Stanford groups, and official Stanford agencies. Correspondents include Hardin Craig,, Helge Kökeritz, Lucia B. Mirrieless, Clark S. Northrup, Louise Pound, John S. P. Tatlock and Philip Sheridan.

did.unittitle: Papers
Correspondence A – C. Includes among miscellaneous correspondence letters from:
Ackermann, Robert W., 1947-50, re An Index of Arthurian Names in Middle English
Alden, Raymond and Donald, 1930-?
Bailey, Margery re request for recommendations
Bonner, Willard D. re conditions in graduate department of English as that time
Briggs, William D. and wife
Bryan, W. F., re bibliography of the English language
Burt, Thomas G. re Kennedy's membership in Phi Beta Kappa
Carruth, W. H. including a report on the Chaucer dictionary
Craig, Hardin
Craigie, W. A.
Curry, Walter C.
Correspondence D – G. Includes among miscellaneous correspondence letters from:
Doane College
Elsasser, Albert
Farnham, O. E. re Rose Bowl
Flügel, Felix re gift of his father's papers (see also, folder on Chaucer Concordance)
Greaves, John re spelling reform
Correspondence H – K. Includes among miscellaneous correspondence letters from:
Hanley, Miles, L. re Hempl papers
Harrer, Charlotte Forster
Hartwig, George H.
Hoover, Herbert re faculty opinion at Stanford (2 letters)
Ichikawa, Sanki re membership in English Literary society of Japan
Jordan, Mrs. David Starr
Kenyon, John S.
Kokeritz, Helge
Correspondence L – P. Includes among miscellaneous correspondence letters from:
Lindberg, J. C.
Lipman, Charles B., Univ. of California re departmental rating
Loomis, Roger S.
Magoun, Francis P.
Meritt, Herbert Dean re "Old English Glosses" report
Mirrielees, Lucia B.
Northrup, Clark S. re Von Patten conflict (see also Middle English Dictionary folder)
Pound, Louise
Correspondence R – S. Includes among miscellaneous correspondence letters from:
Sato, Masaru
Shearin, Mrs. Hubert G. re Dr. Shearin's papers
Stegner, Wallace
Correspondence, Philip Sheridan

Philip Sheridan was a graduate student of Prof. Kennedy whose studies were interrupted by World War II. Dr. Kennedy's letters deal extensively with Stanford, in general, and the Department of English, in particular, during the war years. (for more Sheridan material, see also SC 255 John McClelland Papers)
Correspondence T – Z. Includes among miscellaneous correspondence letters from:
Tatlock, John S. P. (see also, folder on Chaucer Concordance)
Taylor, W. A. re academic standards for graduation
Tucker, Gilbert M.
Vizetelly, Dr. Frank H., 1924-1926, re Funk and Wagnalls Dictionaries
Wintors, Ivor
Zandvoort, R. W.
Academic Associations, membership in and correspondence with:
American Association of University Professors
California Writers Club (see correspondence with Katharine Bennett)
Linquistic Society of America (see correspondence with Aurelio M. Espinosa)
Mediaeval Academy of America
Middle English Language and Literature (see correspondence with A. C. Baugh)
Modern Language Association of America
Phi Beta Kappa (see corespondence with Thomas G. Burt)
Simplified Spelling Association
Family affairs and correspondence:
Letters, genelaogical references, family business
Also, Palo Alto concerns.
Office of the President, Stanford University, official correspondence with:
Administrative actions relating both to the English Department as a whole and to Dr. Kennedy in particular – salary, departmental organization, academic council, parking problems, etc., 1917-1953
Stanford Groups and Organizations, membership in and correspondence with:
Academic Council
Fellowhip Forum
The Research Club of Stanford University
Residents Club of Palo Alto
Stanford Faculty Club
Stanford Library Association
American Speech:

American Speech was a "quarterly of linguistic usage" to which Dr. Kennedy often contributed reveiws and articles. This folder contains correspondence with W. Cabell Greet, long-time editor of the magazine, material relating to the bibliography of American Speech, and other letters and material relating to the quarterly.

unittitle.title: Bibliographical Guides for the Study of English

did.unittitle: Reviews, letters requesting copies, critical comments by colleagues

unittitle.title: A Bibliography of Writings on the English Language

did.unittitle: Letters requesting copies, critical comments by colleagues
A Concise Bibliography for Students of English, Systematically Arranged; 2nd ed, 3rd ed.:
Copy of "Forward," clipping of review, Kennedy's directions to the editor, notes involved in the Bibliography's preparation, critical comments by colleagues
A Concordance to the Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer and to the Raumont of the Rose:

Letter to the President of the Carnegie Institution (1916) on "history, present state, and prospects of the Chaucer concordance," correspondence with John S. P. Tatlock concerning the book, copy of "Instructions to collaborators," copy of "Chaucer research in progress in 1941," list of contents of various boxes of materials ready for printing
Letters requesting copies, correspondence with the publisher, ciritical comments from colleagues
Notes involved in preparation of English Usage, correspondence with the publishers, critical comments from colleagues, clipping of a review of the book
The Middle English Dictionary:

Correspondence with Clark Northrup, editor, and with others concerned in the publication; copy of "Observations concerning a standardized spelling for the main entries in the MED;" copy of "an announcement of the Middle English dictionary;" copy of the reprint, The Middle English Dictionary, L-Laik; minutes of the committee on the English Period Dictionaries
Thorndike-Barnhart Junior and Collegiate Dictionaries:
Comments made by Kennedy in his capacity as a member of the editorial board, and other correspondence with the publisher
J. C. Lindberg and A. G. Kennedy. An Outline of English Grammar, 1st and rev. eds
J. C. Lindberg and A. G. Kennedy. English Grammar for Secondary Schools, Parts I and II,
Grade books from Dr. Kennedy's years as a teacher
A. G. Kennedy. A Bibliography of Writings on the English Language; from the beginnnings of printing to the end of 1922. Harvard University Press
A. G. Kennedy. A Concise Bibliography for Students of English, Systematically Arranged. Stanford University Press
Notebook #1, Volume I. Materials pertaining to The Anglo-Saxon Reader
Correspondence with George Philip Krapp, co-author of the Anglo-Saxon Reader
Correspondence with Henry Holt and Co., Inc.
critical comments and suggestions by academic colleagues
Contents also include sample tables of contents, notes and plans used in organizations of the materials, examples of slips used in glossary, and tables of materials
Notebook #2, Volume I. Materials pertaining to Bibliography of Writings on the English Language c. 1927 (1st of 2 notebooks)
Correspondence with Harvard University Press and Yale University Press, joint publishers
Critical comments and suggestions by academic colleagues
2 letters from Ray Lyman Wilbur, polite inquiries about Dr. Kennedy's progress on his book

Contents also include copy of a paper on need for a bibliography of the English language read at a meeting of the Philological Association of the Pacific Coast, Nov. 28, 1919; reprint of "A Bibliography of the Enlgish Language" appearing in the Correspondence section of Modern Language Notes; samples of prefaces; list of periodicals to be used in work on the Bibliography; table of contents; typographical notes; note to the editor and/or proofreader; and rules for Index.
Notebook #3, Volume II. Materials pertaining to Bibliography of Writings on the English Language c. 1927 (2nd of 2 notebooks)
Correspondence with Harvard University Press and Yale University Press, joint publishers
Critical comments and suggestions by academic colleagues
2 letters from Ray Lyman Wilbur congratulating Kennedy on his book
Correspondence from academic colleagues re A Concordance to the Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer

Contents also include: copy of "A Biblopgraphy of Writings on the English Language from the Beginning of Printing to the end of 1922," a note to appear in the Fall Announcement, 1926, Harvard University Press; paper, "The Making of a Bibliography" (not further identified); review list for book; notes to the editor about corrections; and royalty statements.
Notebook #4, Volume I. Materials pertaining to Current English (1st of 2 notebooks)
Correspondence Correspondence with Ginn and Co., publishers
Criticisms and suggestions re manuscript from academic colleagues
Letters to various publishers requesting permission to use copyrighted materials

Contents also include: Agenda (Kennedy's schedule for work on the book); lists of errata; tenative plan of book; sample table of contents; copy of statement of plans and goals--"A Select Bibliography of Writings on Modern English"; pagination of first draft; typed comments requested by Ginn and Co. from four authorities in the field; and rejected portions of the manuscript.
Notebook #5, Volume II. Materials pertaining to Current English(2nd of 2 notebooks)
Correspondence with Ginn and Co.
Critical comments and suggestions by academic colleagues

Contents also include: copy of pamphlet in memory of Roswell Thornton Pearl (1887-1934), one of Ginn's editors; copies of announcement of book and advertising circulars; list of periodicals for review; notes and instructions to the editors and/or proofreaders; and clipping of review in the San Francisco Examiner.
